Introduction What is a Set? You are all familiar with the idea of sets of objects, the notions of set membership, union, intersection etc. The curly brackets. This is perhaps the most primitive notion in mathematics. Cantor wrote (as translated in [11]): “By an “aggregate” [set] we are to understand any collection into a whole M of deﬁnite and separate objects m of our intuition or our thought. These objects we call the “elements” of M. In signs we express this thus: M = {m}. ” One of the achievements of Set Theory is to give (arguably) a framework in which all mathematics can be formalised: in particular all mathematical objects may be conceived in terms of sets. We will sketch how this can be carried out. Therefore, the “set” notion should be conceived as broadly as possible: any collection we can “comprehend” should be a set. However, a very broad interpretation of a set as the “extension” of a property leads to problems. Paradoxes Early in the development of Set Theory, paradoxes (“antinomies”) were found showing that a naive formalisation of Set Theory, in which one has unrestricted “com- prehension” of sets, leads to inconsistencies. Naive comprehension means: given a prop- erty ϕ(x), formulated in some suitable language, one can forma set whose elements are all the sets with that property. I.e. for each ϕ(x) the axiom: ∃X∀x(x ∈ X ↔ϕ(x)). Taking for ϕ(x) the property “x does not belong to itself” leads to a problem as each of X ∈ X and X /∈ X imply the other. Since we must have either X ∈ X or X /∈ X, such a system is inconsistent. This is Russell’s Paradox (though found independently also by Zermelo). Russell’s 1902 letter to Frege showed that Frege’s proposed foundational systemfor mathematics was inconsistent. Other, more technical, paradoxes were found by Cantor and Burali-Forti (see [18, 26]). They involve objects that are “too big” to be sets. In view of these antinomies, one must be careful in formulating the basic axioms of Set Theory. In particular, and interestingly, one cannot allow naive comprehension, though it seems natural. A pertinent question is: What is an element of set? You are familiar with integers as elements of N,Z, and with rational, or real, or complexnumbers as elements of Q,R,C. But what are individual rational/real/complex numbers? We know that (e.g.) a group consists of a set of elements with a (suitable) composition law deﬁned on it. What are the elements of a group supposed to be? They are permitted to be “anything”, and can typically be integers, rational/real/complex numbers, matrices, functions on any of the above. It is convenient to formulate set theory in such a way that we deal only with sets, so the elements of a set are also sets. Such sets are called hereditary sets. This is not necessary, but very neat. 1 What is Set Theory? Set Theory is the mathematical study of sets and membership, formalized in some suitable way. There are several ways to do this. We will work with ZFC, a variant of the ﬁrst such formalisation due to Zermelo (the ‘Z’) as reﬁned by Fraenkel (the ‘F’) and with the Axiom of Choice (the ‘C’). ZFC is an appealing setup and the most commonly adopted formalisation of Set Theory. In Set Theory one can study foundational issues, since all mathematics can (ar- guably) be formulated there, and mathematical issues, mainly around inﬁnite sets. The origins Historical comments here and throughout are largely drawn from Jech [7]. Set theory was created by George Cantor (1845-1918) in the years 1874-1897. He was led to his ideas by certain problems in real analysis (Fourier series). In 1874 Cantor discovered that one cannot enumerate the real numbers by the natural numbers, showing that inﬁnite sets come in diﬀerent “sizes”. It was a marvellous period of discovery. The axioms for set theory (except for the Replacement Scheme and Foundation Axiom) are due to Zermelo in 1908. This period, with Hilbert’s programme and G¨odel’s theorems, was a fascinating period generally in logic and foundations. Our objectives These are set out in more detail in the course synopsis. Essentially we study: (1) ZFC, Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with the Axiom of Choice. (2) Formalization of mathematics within ZFC (though not in too much detail). (3) Inﬁnite cardinal numbers and ordinal numbers and their arithmetic. The natural numbers are ordinarily used in two distinct ways: as cardinal numbers they express the size of a set, or as ordinal numbers they assign an ordering to elements of a set. Ona cheque, the amount is a cardinal number, the other numbers appearing are ordinals (example from Bedford [30]). Cantor extended the notions of cardinal and ordinal numbers to inﬁnite sets. (4) The Axiom of Choice. Historically controversial (though see [3, p4]), it is now generally accepted. Key questions (beyond this course) are whether it is (a) consistent with and (b) independent from the other axioms. The answers are: ‘yes’ (Godel [15]) and ‘yes’ (Cohen [12]). The ﬁrst ‘yes’ is part of the course in Axiomatic Set Theory. In this course we want to get some appreciation of the function of this axiom, so we don’t introduce it until late in the course. What we won’t cover/Reading We will spend little time on the origins and the paradoxes – and generally on the ideas informing and surrounding Set Theory. E.g. What mathematical objects “are”, whether inﬁnity “exists”, whether the Axiom of Choice is “true”. I highly recommend the books by Goldrei [1], Lavine [3], Rucker [4], and Stillwell [28] as excellent places to start gaining further insight on these issues, and historical ﬁne grain. 2 Goldrei is also our text and should be read for what we are going to study as well as material going beyond our syllabus. Other books to refer to on course material are listed in the course synopsis. Some further reading is suggested at the end of the notes. 2. The language of set theory and the ﬁrst axioms The language of set theory The Language of Set Theory is the language of First Order Predicate Calculus (FOPC) having one non-logical symbol “∈”, a binary relation which is supposed to denote the membership relation x ∈ X between two sets. FOPC is the main topic in B1.1 Logic. It is the most common setup for the logical study of mathematical structures, such as completeness, incompleteness, etc. Deﬁnition. The language L of set theory consists of the following symbols: the binary relation symbol ∈, the logical symbols ∧, ∨, ¬, →, ∀, ∃, =, (note that = is considered as a logical symbol) and brackets (, ) so that we can unambiguously parse formulae, and an inﬁnite list of variables which we will denote x, y, z, X, Y, Z, a, b, c,... (and other letters) which will range over sets. Finally we have the predicates ∀, ∃ (“for all” and “there exists”) also range over sets. Note that the language does not (!) contain the symbols {,}, which (like other symbols) we introduce and use informally. The “meaningful” or well-formed strings of symbols in L are called formulae. Though we say “meaningful”, in fact this a purely syntactic concept. The formulae are deﬁned as follows, starting with the atomic formulae. Deﬁnition. An atomic formula is an expression of the form x ∈ y, or x = y for some variables x,y. 3 The collection of formulae is built from the atomic formulae by recursively using the logical connectives and quantiﬁers Deﬁnition. The set of formulae is deﬁned recursively as follows: 1. An atomic formula is a formula. 2. If ϕ,ψ are formulae then so are (ϕ∧ψ), (ϕ∨ψ), (ϕ →ψ), ¬ϕ. 3. If ϕ is a formula and x is a variable then ∀xϕ and ∃xϕ are formulae. An occurence of a variable in a formula is bound if it is in the scope of a quantiﬁer; otherwise it is free. We recall that a formula ϕ →ψ is logically equivalent to ¬ϕ∨ψ, i.e. it is true unless ϕ is true and ψ is false, and in particular it is true if ϕ is false. We won’t be too formal, in particular about the use of brackets, which are just to ensure correct readability. We will see that statements about sets in “ordinary” mathematical English may be expressed by formulae in L. You will hopefully become comfortable with this. However working completely in Lquickly gets cumbersome (as we will see!). So we will introduce further symbols and express arguments in the usual mathematical way, but those of you who have seen, or will see, FOPC (as in B1.1 or equivalent) should see that everything could be done formally in L. See Goldrei [1], §4.2. A formal language is necessary in order to make our axiom system (in particular the comprehension and replacement axiom schemes) precise, (and so avoid paradoxes). It also means that the whole system can be studied formally, as is done in Part C Axiomatic Set Theory. As mentioned we will introduce additional notation, observing that formulae us- ing the additional notation can be equivalently expressed without it, though in a less readable form. E.g. we will want to use familiar things like curly brackets, union and intersection symbols in the usual ways. Example. The L formula ∀x ( x ∈ y →x ∈ z ) expresses what we would say as “y is a subset of z”. We will write informally “y ⊆ z,” bearing in mind that we have deﬁned this by means of the L-formula above. Note. For me y ⊂ x denotes “y is a subset of x” allowing equality. Others interpret this as a “proper subset”, excluding equality. I believe the former is more natural but I will try to avoid the issue by using ⊆. The ﬁrst axioms We now come to the ﬁrst axioms. These start simply then speed up somewhat. ZF1 – The axiom of extensionality: Two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements. In L this may be expressed by the formula ∀x∀y ( (x = y) ↔∀z(z ∈ x ↔z ∈ y) ) . Note: ϕ ↔ψ means (ϕ →ψ) ∧(ψ →ϕ). This axiom serves to formalise the fact that 4 we will deal only with sets. Oberve also that equality depends just on what elements are in the set (it’s “extension”), not on how it was deﬁned. ZF2 – Null set axiom: There exists a set having no elements. In L this may be expressed by the formula ∃x∀y(¬(y ∈ x)). Note. We will also use x /∈ y, as a shorthand for ¬(x ∈ y), and then we can write the null set axiom equivalently as ∃x∀y(y /∈ x). With these two axioms we may prove a theorem. 2.1. Theorem. There is a unique set having no elements. For those with B1.1 (or equivalent): the theoremmay be expressed in L by the formula [ ∀x∀y ( (x = y) ↔∀z(z ∈ x ↔z ∈ y) ) ∧∃x∀y ( ¬(y ∈ x) )] →∃x ( ∀t¬(t ∈ x) ∧∀y ( ∀w(w /∈ y) →y = x )) . It is not very readable, but is formally provable inFOPC(ﬁrst-order predicate calculus). However, we will be proving theorems in the “usual” style, e.g. as follows. Proof. By ZF2 there is an empty set x. Suppose y is also an empty set. Then x and y have the same elements (i.e. none), and so are equal by ZF1. (I.e. for every z, z ∈ x ↔z ∈ y is true because BOTH z ∈ x and z ∈ y are false). 2.2. Deﬁnition. The set with no elements is called the empty set and (informally) denoted ∅. The term and symbol are of course standard. Formally, ∅ is not in our language, but informally we will use it, remembering that any formula ϕ using ∅ can be ex- pressed equivalently without ∅, as follows. Form a new formula ψ(z) by replacing each occurrence of ∅ by a new variable z (there might also be other free variables). Now form Φ = ∀z ( ∀w(w /∈ z) →ψ(z) ) . Of course this restatement uses additional quantiﬁers, but has not changed what is expressed. Since the empty set is a unique object it is harmless to give it a name. Several subsequent axioms assert that, given some sets x,y,z,..., some other sets exist, such as unordered pairs, union etc, and enable us to start building a reasonable “universe” of sets. Otherwise we would only have ∅. ZF3 – Unordered pairs: If x,y are any two sets there is a set whose elements are precisely x and y. This may be expressed in L as: ∀x∀y∃z ( x ∈ z∧y ∈ z∧∀w(w ∈ z →[w = x∨w = y]) ) . 5 Given x,y the set z is unique (see Problem Set 1, but fairly clear) and will be denoted {x,y}. That is, we will add {,} to our language as well, and allow ourselves to write unordered pairs in this way. As with ∅, this makes our language more readable without actually changing what can be expressed. Observe that, if x is a set, then {x} = {x,x} is a set by ZF3. In mathematics we very often use ordered pairs, e.g. cartesian coordinates, and say e.g. that a function is a set of ordered pairs. However, sets are unordered. So we introduce a somewhat cumbersome device to “imitate” ordered pairs. Once we have seen that it works, we will introduce a notation for ordered pairs and proceed to use it in the usual ways. 2.3. Deﬁnition. Let x,y be sets. The set {{x},{x,y}} is called the ordered pair of x and y. The set x is called the ﬁrst coordinate, and y the second coordinate, of the ordered pair. We set ⟨x,y⟩ = {{x},{x,y}}. For the deﬁnition to “work” means (1) with every ordered pair (x,y) of sets we associate a set ⟨x,y⟩ which will serve as the ordered pair. This we clearly have, using our pairs axiom, twice: {x} is a set and {x,y} is a set so {{x},{x,y}} is a set. (2) given a set z it can be the ordered pair ⟨x,y⟩ for only one ordered pair of sets (x,y), i.e we can uniquely recover x as ﬁrst coordinate and y as second coordinate given only the set ⟨x,y⟩. This is established by the following theorem. 2.4. Theorem. Let x,y,u,v be sets. If ⟨x,y⟩ = ⟨u,v⟩ then x = u and y = v. Proof. Suppose that {{x},{x,y}} = {{u},{u,v}}. We will heavily use ZF1 (extensionality), referring to {{u},{u,v}} as “RHS” (easier to write down). Suppose x = y (which is certainly not excluded). Then {x,y} = {x} and {{x},{x,y}} = {{x},{x}} = {{x}} is a set with just one element {x}. By ZF1, each element of RHS is an element of LHS, so {u} = {x}, {u,v} = {x} so that {u,v} = {u}, which implies u = v, and u = x, and so y = x = u = v. If u = v, a symmetrical argument gives x = y = u. So we can assume that x ̸= y and u ̸= v. Since {x} is an element of LHS, it must be an element of the RHS. As RHS has just two element, we are in one of two cases. Case 1: {x} = {u,v}. This implies u = x,v = x, whence u = v, a contradiction. So we must be in Case 2: {x} = {u}, which implies x = u. 6 Next {x,y} is an element of RHS, and {x,y} = {u} leads to a contradiction. So we have {x,y} = {u,v}. Now y must equal one of the elements u,v of (new) RHS. But y = u and u = x leads to x = y, a contradiction. So y = v. Note. Observe the vital importance of using the right number of {}’s, as I hope I did. Please be extremely careful, as x,{x},{{x}} etc are diﬀerent sets. The set x may have many elements, may be inﬁnite, or might be empty, while {x} always has precisely one element: x. The set {{x}} also has precisely one element but it is {x}, not x. And please let me know if I make slips of this kind (or other kinds) in notes or lectures. This gives us individual ordered pairs. We will want to form Cartesian products of any two sets as a set of ordered pairs. This will come a bit later. One thing we certainly want is to take unions (and intersections, complements etc). This is accomplished in a somewhat round-about way. ZF4 – Unions: Given a set x, there is a set consisting of all the elements of all the elements of x. In L this may be expressed by the formula ∀x∃y∀z ( z ∈ y ↔∃w ( z ∈ w∧w ∈ x )) . The set whose existence is asserted above is denoted ⋃ x. It is what we would mean by the “naive” comprehension ⋃x = {z : ∃w ∈ x : z ∈ w}. 2.5. Proposition. If x,y are sets, the union of x and y is a set. Proof. By pairs, we formz = {x,y}. The elements of ⋃ z = ⋃ {x,y} are then precisely the elements of x and y, so it is the union of x and y. The union of x and y will be denoted x∪y in the usual way. This axiom will also allow us to deﬁne inﬁnite unions as unions over inﬁnite sets, while an axiom asserting the existence of x∪y would extend to ﬁnite unions, but not to inﬁnite ones. ZF5 – Comprehension scheme: If ϕ(z,w1,...,wk) is a formula in L, with free variables among z,w1,...,wk, and x is a set then for any sets w1,...,wk there is set y consisting of the elements z of x for which ϕ(z,w1,...,wk) holds. In L (possibly clearer!): If ϕ(z,w1,...,wk) is a formula of L whose free variables are among z,w1,...,wk (and so “asserts something” about z,w1,...,wk), then ∀x∀w1 ...∀wk∃y∀z [ z ∈ y ↔( z ∈ x∧ϕ(z,w1,...,wk) )] . The wi are “parameters”. This set y will be denoted {z ∈ x : ϕ(z,w1,...,wk)}. Observe that this is an axiom scheme, one axiomfor each formula ϕ, not a single axiom. It is a much restricted version of naive comprehension – which would give (for each choice of w1,...,wk) a set {z : ϕ(z,w1,...,wk)}. 7 This version proceeds from the idea that a problem with naive comprehension is that it allows one to deﬁne a set by quantifying over a domain that includes the set being deﬁned, even though that set does not exist “yet”. Here we allow comprehension of subsets of a set which already exists. The Comprehension scheme is also called the Subset axiom scheme and the Separation scheme. With this axiom one can do quite a bit. 2.6 Proposition. If x,y are sets, so is their intersection x ∩ y and their diﬀerence x\y. Proof. By comprehension using ϕ(z,w) = z ∈ w and ψ(z,w) = ¬(z ∈ w) respectively and w = y we have x∩y = {z ∈ x : ϕ(z,y)}, x\y = {z ∈ x : ψ(z,y)}. More generally 2.7. Proposition. Let x be a non-empty set. Then the intersection of all elements of x is a set, denoted ⋂x. Proof. The set ⋃ x that we already have includes the set we want as the subset of elements having a certain property, and so ⋂ x = {z ∈ ⋃ x : ∀y (( y ∈ x ) →( z ∈ y )) }. We will avoid deﬁning ⋂∅. Note that if we deﬁned ⋂∅ by saying it is “the set of z such that, for all sets y, if y ∈ x then z ∈ y” we would get all sets! This is not a valid deﬁnition since we are not comprehending z over a set. If we comprehend over ⋃ ∅, as in the proof, then ⋂∅ = ∅, since ⋃∅ = ∅. With this axiom one also ﬁnds that certain sets cannot exist. 2.8. Proposition. There is no set of all sets. Proof. By contradiction. If x is a set we can ‘comprehend’ y = {z ∈ x : z /∈ z}. If there were a set x of all sets then we recover Russell’s Paradox, for y ∈ x, so y ∈ y ↔y /∈ y. Similarly, while we can formset diﬀerences x\y, there is no “absolute” complement (where this idea is used one is always operating inside some ambient set). 2.9. Proposition. Let x be a set. There is no set whose elements are all of the sets ehich are not elements of x. Proof. See Problem Set 1. 8 Note: I try to avoid the word “contain” which can be ambiguous: A “contains”” B could mean B ∈ A or, sometimes, B ⊆ A. Classes Still, it is useful to be able to refer to the “collection” of all sets, and we introduce the informal notion of a class. It is informal in the sense that variables in our language range over sets; classes are not part of the formal setup. 2.10. Deﬁnition. A class is a collection of the form X= {x : ϕ(x)} where ϕ is a formula of L, and x ranges over sets. The formula ϕ is permitted to have other free variables, which we view as parameters. The class V = {x : x = x} is the traditional notation for “the universe” of all sets. Note that the formula is not unique, so a class is not the “same thing” as a formula. A class (being a collection of sets) may be a set, or it may not. A class which is not a set is called a proper class. If a class belongs to another class, then it is a set (since the elements of a class are sets), and since any set belongs to the class V= {x : x = x} of all sets, we see that a proper class is just a class that is not an element of any class, or of any set. We can form Russell’s class Y = {x : x /∈ x} and the paradox disappears, becoming simply a proof that Y is not a set. We will see some other proper classes. If X (as above) and Z = {x : ψ(x)} are classes we can write statements like X⊆ Z (whose truth or falsity depends on X,Z) remembering that this can be rephrased without mentioning classes as ∀x ( ϕ(x) →ψ(x) ) . It is useful for readability to write such statements, but we must be careful not to treat classes as sets (e.g. by “comprehending” over them). 3. The Powerset axiom The ﬁrst of a group of very powerful axioms (especially in combination). 9 ZF6 – Powerset axiom: Let x be a set. There is a set whose elements are precisely the subsets of x. This set is uniquely determined by x (check left to the reader, but similar to Theorem 2.1 and to Problem Set 1, Question 2). 3.1. Deﬁnition. The set of subsets of a set x is called the power set of x, and is denoted P(x). While we have deﬁned individual ordered pairs, the power set axiom enables us to deﬁne Cartesian products. 3.2. Proposition. Let X,Y be sets. There is a set whose elements are all the ordered pairs ⟨x,y⟩ where x ∈ X and y ∈ Y. Proof. The key observation is that, if x ∈ X and y ∈ Y, then {x} ∈ P(X ∪Y), {x,y} ∈ P(X ∪Y) and so ⟨x,y⟩ = {{x},{x,y}} ∈ P ( P ( X ∪Y)) = P. The set we want can then be separated out using the comprehension axiom. The set Z = {z ∈ P : ∃x∃y ( x ∈ X ∧y ∈ Y ∧z = ⟨x,y⟩ ) } has the desired properties: all ordered pairs ⟨x,y⟩,x ∈ X,y ∈ Y are elements of Z (as they all belong to P), and every element in it is such an ordered pair. Of course this set is uniquely determined by X and Y, so we can refer to it as “the” Cartesian product, and give it its usual name and notation. 3.3. Deﬁnition. Let X,Y be sets. The set consisting of all ordered pairs ⟨x,y⟩ where x ∈ X,y ∈ Y is called the Cartesian product of X and Y and denoted X ×Y. Relations and functions 3.4. Deﬁnition. Let X,Y be sets. Arelation between X and Y is a subset R ⊆ X×Y. We sometimes write xRy instead of ⟨x,y⟩ ∈ R. A relation between X and X is called a relation on X. 3.5. Deﬁnition. A relation R ⊆ X ×Y is a function from X to Y if, for all x ∈ X, there exists a unique y ∈ Y such that ⟨x,y⟩ ∈ R. If f is a function from X to Y and ⟨x,y⟩ ∈ f we will write y = f(x). A function will also be called a map (etc). This may of course be expressed by an L-formula: a set F is a function from A to B provided ( F ⊆ A×B ) ∧∀x ( x ∈ A →∃y ( (y ∈ B) ∧((x,y) ∈ F) ∧∀z((x,z) ∈ F →z = y) )) . The collection of all relations between X and Y is just P(X×Y), and so is a set. Inside this we may “comprehend” the set of functions (See Question 1 on Problem Set 2). 10 3.6. Deﬁnition. The set of functions from X to Y is denoted Y X. Note: sometimes the notation XY is used to avoid confusion later with exponentials of cardinal and ordinal numbers. Explanation of this “exponential” notation: suppose X = {a,b} is a two element set. Specifying a function f : X →Y means choosing an element of Y to be f(a), and an element of Y to be f(b). So it amounts to an element of Y ×Y, an ordered pair. If X has 3 elements, one needs 3 choices from Y, i.e. an element of Y ×Y ×Y. In general we choose an element of Y for each element of X, so it is a kind of exponentiation of sets, and the notation works in a familiar way. If f is a function (i.e. a set of ordered pairs) then the domain of f Dom(f) = {x ∈ ⋃⋃ f : ∃y ∈ ⋃⋃ f( ⟨x,y⟩ ∈ f) } is a set (Union, Comprehension) as is the range of f Range(f) = {y ∈ ⋃⋃ f : ∃x ∈ ⋃⋃ f( ⟨x,y⟩ ∈ f) }. If we refer to f : X →Y as a function we mean that X,Y are sets and f is a suitable subset of X×Y. We will make the usual assumption that f is deﬁned on all X, so that Dom(f) = X, but only that Range(f) ⊆ Y. We will also write f[X] for Range(f). We consider a function to be a set of ordered pairs. Thus, two functions are equal if they are the same set of ordered pairs (Extensionality), so the “codomain” of a function is not essential: f : X →Y and g : X →Z can be equal even if Y ̸= Z. Of course the image of a function f is determined by f, and so if f = g as function then we must have f[X] = g[X]. This will be some subset of Y ∩Z. The empty function. According to our deﬁnitions, ∅ is a function from ∅ to ∅. This is because the condition ∀x(x ∈ ∅ → ...) holds vacuously. Indeed, it is injective and surjective. Thus ∅∅ = {∅}. This may seem odd but will be important (it will mean that 00 = 1.) Equivalence relations and order relations Apart from functions, two other special kinds of relations get a lot of attention in mathematics: equivalence relations, and order relations. 3.7. Deﬁnition. An equivalence relation E on a set X is a relation E on X which is (i) Reﬂexive: ⟨x,x⟩ ∈ E for all x ∈ X; (ii) Symmetric: For all x,y ∈ X, if ⟨x,y⟩ ∈ E then ⟨y,x⟩ ∈ E (iii) Transitive: for all x,y,z ∈ X, if ⟨x,y⟩ ∈ E and ⟨y,z⟩ ∈ E then ⟨x,z⟩ ∈ E. There are several kinds of order relations, but they fall into two basic types: the strict ones (like <) and the weak ones (like ≤). 11 3.8. Deﬁnition. Well-orders Here we consider the use of numbers to “enumerate” the elements of a set. What should this mean for inﬁnite sets? This is the key new concept in this course. If we enumerate a set X this will certainly lead to a strict total ordering ≺ of X, since for any two distinct elements one of them will occur “before” the other in the enumeration. But having a total order is not enough: the real numbers are totally ordered by the usual ordering < but this does not at all lend itself to “enumerating” them. Our ordering must give us a “ﬁrst” element, and, at any stage of the enumeration, a “next” element. Here a “stage” means we have already enumerated some subset Y ⊆ X, so Y is such that whenever y ∈ Y and w ≺ y then w ∈ Y too (because it occurs “before” y). 27 11.1. Deﬁnition. A strict total order ≺ on a set X is a well-ordering of X if every non-empty subset S ⊆ X has a least element. Such an order is also called a well-order, and a set X with a well-order on it is called a well-ordered set. A well-order on a set X does give an “enumeration”. At any stage of enumeration, if the subset Y has been enumerated already, we take S = X −Y. If it is empty, we have ﬁnished enumerating X. Otherwise there is a least element of S which serves as the “next” element of X. The deﬁnition gives us a bit more than we really need (we need a least element for any X−Y for Y as above) though in fact the weaker property gives this one. Examples. The set ω = {0,1,2,...} is well ordered by ∈ (this was established as Theorem 4.13). The set Y = {0,1/2,3/4,7/8,15/16,...,(2n −1)/2n,...} is well-ordered by <. The set X = {0,1/2,3/4,7/8,15/16,...,(2n −1)/2n,...,1,3/2,15/8,...,(2.2n −1)/2n,...} is well-ordered by <. The least element of X −Y is 1, the “next” element is 3/2 etc. However the sets {..., 1 n,..., 1 3, 1 2,1}, {0,..., 1 n ,..., 1 3, 1 2,1}, are not well-ordered by <. In the ﬁrst set there is no least element, while in the second set there is no least element among the positive elements. 11.2. Proposition. A strict total ordering of a ﬁnite set is a well-order. The Axiom of Choice In this section we introduce a further axiom, the Axiom of Choice. Everything proved so far has of course been proved without it, but some natural statements turn out to require it – indeed to be equivalent to it. With AC we get a fairly clear picture of ordinals and cardinals. The axiom was controversial in the ﬁrst part of the twentieth century (though see [3, p4]), and some mathematicians are still uncomfortable with it, but it is now generally accepted. We have not proved that the cardinalities of any two sets are comparable. One would naturally like to have the following hold. Cardinal comparability (CC): If X,Y are sets then |X| ≤ |Y| or |Y| ≤ |X|. I.e. either X ≼ Y or Y ≼ X. CCis also called: the “dichotomy principle”. Ordinal numbers were introduced with the idea of “enumerating” sets. One would therefore like to have the following. Well-ordering principle (WO): Every set X may be well-ordered. 15.1. Theorem. Assume WO. Then every set is equinumerous with an ordinal. Proof. Let X be a set. By WO there is a well-order < on X. By Theorem 12.7 the well-ordered set X is order-isomorphic to a (unique) ordinal α. The order-isomorphism is a bijection, so X ∼ α. 15.2. Corollary. WO implies CC. Proof. Let X,Y be sets. By the Theorem we have X ∼ α,Y ∼ β for ordinals α,β. But ordinals are comparable: either α ≤ β or β ≤ α, and composing the relevant maps gives X ≼ Y or Y ≼ X. 41 15.3. Theorem. CC implies WO. Proof. ZFC10 – Axiom of Choice (AC): Let X be a non-empty set of disjoint non- empty sets. Then there exists a set B such that for all A ∈ X we have |A∩B| = 1. Note that B having other elements (“random set junk”) is not excluded. The set B “chooses” one element out of every set A ∈ X, even if there may be no obvious way of doing this. As Russell described it (following Fraenkel): if X is an inﬁnite set of pairs of shoes, one can go through and choose all the left shoes. But if they are pairs of socks, how do we choose? A choice function for a set X is a function f : P(X)\{∅} → X such that f(A) ∈ A for all A ∈ P(X)\{∅}. 15.5. Theorem. ACis equivalent to the statement that every set has a choice function. The formula ϕ(x,y) = (x ∈ P(X)\{∅}) ∧(y ∈ x) ∧(x,y) ∈ B deﬁnes (by replacement) a choice function for X. (One could almost use B itself but it could have random other elements; so could use Comprehension to get rid of these.) ⇐ Let Z be a set of disjoint non-empty sets. A chain in Z is a non-empty subset C of Z with the property that, for any two elements c1,c2 ∈ C, either c1 ⊆ c2 or c2 ⊆ c1. I.e., C is totally ordered by ⊆. 2. Let Z be a set. AC and ZL are equivalent (given the axioms of ZF). Proof. WO implies ZL: Suppose Z is a non-empty set with the chain condition. Let < be a well-ordering of Z. Cardinal numbers Assuming AC, as we now do, the theory of cardinal numbers becomes moderately well-behaved. 16.1. Deﬁnition. An inﬁnite ordinal α is called an initial ordinal if it is not equinu- merous with any strictly smaller ordinal. 16.2. Theorem. Every inﬁnite set is equinumerous with a unique initial ordinal. Proof. Let X be an inﬁnite set. We know (by WO and 15.1) that X is equinumerous with an ordinal γ. Let α be the least such ordinal. Then X ∼ α. Moreover, α is an initial ordinal, for any smaller ordinal equinumerous with α would be equinumerous with X. Similarly α is the unique initial ordinal equinumerous with X (a larger ordinal equinumerous with X is equinumerous with α and so not initial). 16.3. Theorem. Let {βγ : γ ∈ α} be a set of initial ordinals. Then there exists an initial ordinal exceeding all the βγ. Proof. The union λ = ⋃ {βγ : γ ∈ α} is an ordinal. Then P(λ) is equinumerous with some initial ordinal µ, and since |P(λ)| > |λ| ≥ |βγ| for all γ ∈ α we must have βγ < µ for all γ ∈ α. 45 With this Theoremwe may deﬁne initial ordinals ωα for all ordinals αby transﬁnite recursion as follows. 16.4. The “paradox” resulting from the existence of a set comprising all the ordinals is known as the Burali-Forti paradox. Ramsey in 1930. By a graph we mean a vertex set V and a set E of “edges”, E ⊂ V (2), the set of 2-element subsets of V. So edges are undirected, and between each pair of vertices there is either an edge, or not: we don’t allow “multiple” edges, or “loops” on a single vertex. 16.18. Theorem. Let V be a countably inﬁnite set, and E an arbitrary subset of V (2), the set of two-element subsets of V. (So (V,E) is a graph on a countably inﬁnite vertex set.) Then there exists a countably inﬁnite subset W ⊂ V such that the induced graph (W,W(2) ∩E) either has no edges, or is a complete graph. That is W(2) ∩E is either empty or all of W(2). Proof. Let V0 = V and choose some v0 ∈ V0. Now for each v ∈ V0 −{v0}, the edge {v0,v} either belongs to E or not, and one of these sets (at least) is inﬁnite. Let V1 be an inﬁnite such set, choose v1 ∈ V1, and continue. This produces a sequence v0,v1,v2,... which has the following property: each adjacent pair vi,vi+1 either belongs to E or not, and in either case the same holds for vi with every subsequent vj. Now either “belongs to E” or “doesn’t belong to E” holds for inﬁnitely many adjacent pairs vi,vi+1. Choose one of these for which the number of pairs vi,vi+1 is inﬁnite, and take W to be the set of vi. Thus inside an arbitrary graph (V,E), which has no particular structure, is an induced subgraph with a high degree of structure: “complete disorder is impossible” is the slogan of Ramsey Theory. The above theorem has (indeed implies) a ﬁnitary version. The simplest case is: in any group of 6 people, there either exist 3 people who all know each other, or three people who all don’t know each other.
